reviewText: From tvshowsondvd.comThe Equalizer - The Wait Is Over: Universal Announces Season 1 on DVD!Finally on Assignment this February 12thPosted by David Lambert10/30/2007Previously best known as the title character in the 1980 film 'Breaker' Morant, Edward Woodward literally blew American TV audiences away in 1985 as Robert McCall, The Equalizer. The CBS show also included Robert Lansing ("Gary Seven" of the Star Trek episode "Assignment: Earth") as the source of many of McCall's assignments. Lansing's character, "Control", worked for The Company, which used to employee McCall as an operative. Another operative, played by The King of Queen's Jerry Stiller (father of Ben Stiller), gave McCall the nickname "The Equalizer" in the opening episode.Other first-season guest stars beside Jerry Stiller included Lauren Tom, David Alan Grier, Lori Petty (in her first role), Adam Ant, Luis Guzmán, Burt Young, Dana Barron, Bradley Whitford, Christine Baranski, Alex Winter, Charles S. Dutton, Meat Loaf, Mark Linn-Baker, Tovah Feldshuh, Ray Sharkey, Marisa Berenson, Brad Dourif, Jasmine Guy, James Eckhouse, David Leisure, Robert Davi, Melissa Joan Hart, Kim Delaney, Patricia Clarkson, Dann Florek, Tony Shalhoub, Laurie Metcalf, Dan Hedaya, and probably a lot of others that we missed. Whew!This morning Universal Studios Home Entertainment officially announced that you'll be able to get all 22 first-year episodes on 5 DVDs when they release The Equalizer - Season 1. This long-awaited set, in high demand with registered members of this site, will finally see the light of day on February 12th. Episodes will be shown in their original full-screen video format, and with English Dolby Digital 2.0 audio. There will also be English Subtitles available for the hearing impaired. Cost will be $49.98 SRP. We don't have cover art yet, but stay tuned and we'll bring that to you just as soon as we get it!

reviewText: Not bad, but there are much better episodes that could have been released. Please release more! This is one of the last of the best TV shows that was really original. They don't make them like this any more.

reviewText: Where is the Equalizer when we need him? Is this all we have left to remember him by? What a great show. There were some really good episodes. This one will have to do for now. I could hardly wait each week to see it. Now I wait for a DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Like the earlier reviewer, I feel that this one does not showcase the great writing and acting of this moderate "hit" from the 80's.  Edward Woodard is excellent as the enigmatic Robert McCall, vigilante with a hidden agenda directed against his former employers - a cleverly disguised "take" on our own CIA.For the uninitiated, this tape is entertaining, but there are so many other installments that are much more satisfying.  However, "Memories" is still a good introduction to one of television's "coolest" characters.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Equalizer" was thinking man's television in the 1980s.  "Miami Vice" had glitz, glamor, was well written; but because of the time period--the fashions, the hairstyles, and the topics--now seems dated.  This series seemed to be able to capture the smarts and grittiness of New York, and the gray areas of the intelligence field; and it seems timeless.  James McAdams created a wonderful character in Robert McCall, and lucked into a wonderful actor to play McCall--for those who don't know the story, McAdams originally created the series as a vehicle for James Coburn, but Coburn's longtime problems with arthritis wouldn't let him take the role.  So McAdams had to find someone else to fill the McCall role.  The whole upshoot was that Edward Woodward didn't just play the world-weary ex-spy turned private investigator, he BECAME Robert McCall.This two-parter delved into McCall's past; a lost love who he worked with in his previous life, and discovering a daughter that Manon didn't let him know he had.  Woodward was brilliant in this episode as was Anthony Zerbe as the man Manon married and treated Yvette as his own.  Melissa Sue Anderson was very good as Yvette, and Keith Szarabajka was consistenly solid as McCall's occasional partner (both within the Company and in McCall's private enterprise) Mickey Kostmayer.  This was a story that allowed the viewer into the past of Robert McCall; reminding him of some regrets, of choices made and paths taken.  The action is tense, but the drama is sad and remorseful.It seems odd that "Miami Vice" will be done as a feature length film this summer.  I worry about it having a dated feel.  "The Equalizer" seemed capable of telling much more timeless stories, with this two-parter being a good example.
Title: N/A

reviewText: My husband is the all time biggest fan of the equalizer. He once had a toothache and he called me at work and asked me to make him a dental appointment. I called him back to say they could see him at 3pm and he refused to go because the equalizer was going to begin at that time. I made him tape the episode so that he could keep the appointment! (Mind you, it was a re-run but that never seemed to matter to him!) He always used to sit and "analyze" the episode after it ended. He finally turned me into a fan too! Please consider putting the episodes on DVD for each season, my husband would love me for a million years if I bought them for him!
Title: N/A
